ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Possibly. It's a good pre-industrial but the material can be arcane. Those interested in Chinese history will find parallels.

This course is a survey of Vietnamese history. It covers a huge time period for a history seminar, and the readings span a lot of topics, though it's never really clear how much of the reading is entirely necessary--the more the better, but no expectation to finish it all. The class was small, but discussions were generally good, though at times they would drag on a bit. Professor Kiernan is friendly and helpful, and creates a good atmosphere in seminar.

History 382J deals with the history of Vietnam (and, to a certain extent, the rest of the region, at least when nearby countries were competing with Vietnam for territory or falling under Vietnamese control) up through the early 20th century. I would recommend the course, especially if your only knowledge of Vietnam is the Vietnam War and you want to learn more about the country.

The course is an in-depth survey of Vietnam's history. Unless you have a serious interest in the subject material, I would not recommend this class. It is very thorough and exhaustive, or at least it felt that way. If you are planning on being a Vietnamese historian or even a Chinese specialist, there would be no better course and reading list for understanding traditional Vietnamese history.
